TopicTitle: Rocket with clipped parts shakes itself apart on the launch pad.

Articles.Content:
I'm trying to make a rocket that looks somewhat like the Proton using stock parts. I really like the appearance of it's first stage. http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/14/Proton_Zvezda_crop.jpg

I had to use parts clipping to get that distinct shape though. It seems fine until I take it out to launch, it starts shaking harder and harder until things start exploding. Putting the rocket on launch clamps helped a bit, but it only delayed the self-destructive shaking. The after mission report says that some of the X200 fuel tanks impacted one another. Is there something I'm doing wrong? I've seen people use parts clipping like this for aesthetic purposes before and they didn't seem to have this problem. I know it's kind of cheating and all that, but this won't be for any serious challenges, I just want to build a cool retro-rocket with a soviet vibe to it.

Here's a screengrab of it in the launchpad. http://i.imgur.com/Fy7GepX.png

I'd also like to clip the engines into the fuel tanks somewhat, so only the very bottom of the engine bells stick out. Still working on how I'm going to do that. Thanks in advance for any help/tips/tricks.

Add more struts!

And with that engine just place it between the two tanks above it.

The struts actually did help... so, thanks for that. But I'm running into another problem right away. I placed the parts with 6 times symmetry but the engines aren't using fuel in the same way. Some are feeding from the central tank, some are ignoring it and just using the fuel they have in the tanks above them. The results is that one engine will run out of fuel before the others, sending the whole thing tumbling out of control.

http://i.imgur.com/niJBxuR.png

http://i.imgur.com/cLS2ro1.png

I've tried to eliminate as many clipped parts as possible, and I noticed that when I removed all of the clipped parts the problem went away. In the pics the only clipped part that remains is the end-caps on the 6 outside stacks. And even just that is enough to trigger the buggy fuel flow.

Clipping parts is cheating, the game is just enforcing that.

(On a serious note, my experience with fuel flow and massively clipped boosters has been a bit frustrating. You will need to be creative with the fuel pumps.)

When dealing with large numbers of clipped tanks I often had similar problems, and in the end the only solution that worked for me was to install the TAC fuel balancer mod, and before launch set it to automatically keep all affected tanks balanced for fuel and oxidizer. Then as the engines drew from whatever fuel tank they damn well wanted to, TAC fuel balancer would move remaining fuel around to maintain the balance.

In the end I managed to build something half-way decent without any clipping. I attached the end-caps on the grey X200s then rose them until they were nestled into the 3.75 m separator. The game seems to accept this without throwing a hissy-fit.

http://i.imgur.com/1XGrCS3.png

It ends up being a surprisingly powerful lifter, worthy of the fury of 6 Main Sails. I managed to get the last stage up into orbit with an almost full fuel tank. The real Proton is much more slim and tall, but... for now it's the best I can manage without building parts from scratch in Blender.
